column2: Wall St Week Ahead-Stocks could resume gains as focus shifts to earnings NEW YORK
column3: April 2 Market focus will shift from macro to micro next week as economic data winds down and quarterly earnings reports from S&P; 500 components including Alcoa take center-stage.

column2: Funding Circle to get Temasek
column3: Blackrock funding - Sky LONDON
column4: April 2 Singapore's sovereign wealth fund Temasek and money manager BlackRock are set to buy stakes in Funding Circle in deals that could value the British peer-to-peer lending platform at more than $1 billion

column2: Simon Property to buy back $2 bln in stock after Macerich snub April 2 Simon Property Group Inc
column3: the largest U.S. shopping mall owner
column4: said it would buy back $2 billion in stock
column5: less than 48 hours after scrapping an attempt to buy rival Macerich Co.

column2: Mattel appoints Christopher Sinclair as CEOUPDATE 2-Mattel appoints Christopher Sinclair as CEO * Shares fall as much as 3.3. pct   (Adds analyst comment

column4: background; updates shares)  UPDATE 2-Mattel appoints Christopher Sinclair as CEO * Shares fall as much as 3.3. pct   (Adds analyst comment
column6: background; updates shares) April 2 Barbie doll maker Mattel Inc  appointed Christopher Sinclair its Chief Executive
column7: two months after the former PepsiCo Inc executive was named interim CEO.UPDATE 2-Mattel appoints Christopher Sinclair as CEO * Shares fall as much as 3.3. pct   (Adds analyst comment

column2: McDonald's raising average worker wage to about $10 an hourMcDonald's wage plan renews debate on independence of franchiseesMcDonald's wage plan renews debate on independence of franchiseesMcDonald's wage plan renews debate on independence of franchisees NEW YORK/LOS ANGELES McDonald's Corp's  announcement that it will raise the average pay at its company-operated U.S. restaurants threatens to complicate an ongoing labor dispute that turns on whether McDonald's can be held responsible for the labor violations of  its franchisees.  McDonald's wage plan renews debate on independence of franchisees NEW YORK/LOS ANGELES McDonald's Corp's  announcement that it will raise the average pay at its company-operated U.S. restaurants threatens to complicate an ongoing labor dispute that turns on whether McDonald's can be held responsible for the labor violations of  its franchisees.
